Gingerbread Pancakes

Jump to Recipe

Are you ready to bring the warm, festive flavors of gingerbread into your breakfast routine? These Gingerbread Pancakes are the perfect way to spice up your mornings, especially during the holiday season. With a delightful blend of ground ginger, cinnamon, and nutmeg, these pancakes not only taste amazing but also fill your kitchen with a cozy aroma that will make everyone eager to sit down for a meal. Made with easy-to-find ingredients like all-purpose flour, brown sugar, and molasses, this recipe is simple enough for a weekday breakfast yet special enough for holiday brunch gatherings. If you're looking for a recipe that combines the nostalgic flavors of gingerbread cookies with the fluffy texture of pancakes, look no further! Let’s dive into this delightful recipe that will surely become a family favorite.

Ingredients

all-purpose flour

All-purpose flour is versatile, but for a healthier option, you can substitute half with whole wheat flour. Sift the flour before measuring for a lighter texture.

baking powder

Ensure your baking powder is fresh for optimal rise. If you don't have baking powder, you can use 1/2 tsp of baking soda plus 1 tsp of vinegar or lemon juice as a substitute.

baking soda

Baking soda is a base and needs an acid to activate it. If you don't have it, you can omit it if using baking powder, but it may slightly affect the texture.

ground ginger

For a fresh flavor, you can use freshly grated ginger instead of ground. If you enjoy spiciness, increase the amount to 1.5 tsp.

ground cinnamon

Cinnamon adds warmth; consider using Ceylon cinnamon for a sweeter flavor. You can also mix in a pinch of cardamom for added complexity.

ground nutmeg

Use freshly grated nutmeg for a more potent flavor. If you're out of nutmeg, you can omit it, or replace it with a bit more cinnamon.

brown sugar

Light brown sugar works well, but you can use dark brown sugar for a deeper molasses flavor. Alternatively, coconut sugar can be a lower glycemic index substitute.

salt

Salt enhances flavor; consider using sea salt or kosher salt for a different texture. You can reduce the amount slightly if you're on a low-sodium diet.

milk

Dairy-free milk alternatives such as almond or oat milk can be used without compromising the recipe. If using buttermilk, reduce the baking powder slightly.

egg

If you need an egg substitute, use 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce or 1/4 cup of yogurt. This will alter the texture slightly but keep the pancakes moist.

molasses

Molasses adds richness; if unavailable, you can substitute with honey or maple syrup, but it will change the flavor profile. Blackstrap molasses is the least sweet but rich in nutrients.

butter

Melted butter adds flavor; you can substitute with coconut oil for a dairy-free option. For a lower-fat alternative, use applesauce.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a large bowl, combine 1 cup of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons of baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda, 1 teaspoon of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon, 1/4 teaspoon of ground nutmeg, 2 tablespoons of brown sugar, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Stir well to ensure all dry ingredients are evenly distributed. This mixture will provide the base flavors for your gingerbread pancakes.
    Tip:
    Use a whisk to aerate the flour, which helps make the pancakes fluffier.

  • Step 2: Prepare Wet Ingredients

    In a separate bowl, whisk together 1 cup of milk, 1 large egg, 2 tablespoons of molasses, and 2 tablespoons of melted butter. Mixing these ingredients together first ensures that the molasses is well incorporated, preventing clumping.
    Note:
    If your molasses is too thick, warm it slightly in the microwave to make it easier to mix.

  • Step 3: Combine Wet and Dry Ingredients

    Pour the wet mixture into the bowl of dry ingredients. Stir gently until just combined, being careful not to overmix; a few lumps are perfectly fine. Overmixing can lead to tough pancakes. Expert Tip: If the batter seems too thick, you can add a splash of milk to reach the desired consistency.

  • Step 4: Heat the Skillet

    Place a skillet or griddle over medium heat and lightly grease it with butter or oil. Allow the skillet to heat up for a few minutes until it's hot enough that a drop of water sizzles on contact.
    Note:
    If your pancakes are browning too quickly, reduce the heat slightly.

  • Step 5: Cook the Pancakes

    Pour about 1/4 cup of batter for each pancake onto the skillet. Cook for 2-3 minutes or until bubbles form on the surface and the edges look set. Carefully flip the pancakes and cook for another 2-3 minutes on the other side until golden brown. Expert Tip: Use a spatula to gently lift the edge of the pancake before flipping to check for doneness.

  • Step 6: Serve and Enjoy

    Serve the pancakes warm with maple syrup, whipped cream, fresh fruit, or your favorite toppings. For an extra touch, sprinkle with powdered sugar or drizzle with honey.
    Note:
    These pancakes can be made ahead of time and kept warm in a 200°F (93°C) oven until ready to serve.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best way to measure flour accurately?

To measure flour, spoon it into your measuring cup and level it off with a straight edge. Avoid scooping directly from the bag, as it can pack the flour and lead to using too much.

How do I know when the pancakes are ready to flip?

Look for bubbles forming on the surface of the pancakes. When they start to pop and the edges look set, it's time to flip!

What can I use instead of molasses?

If you don’t have molasses, you can substitute it with honey or maple syrup, but the flavor will be slightly different.

How can I prevent pancakes from sticking to the skillet?

Make sure your skillet is preheated to medium heat and lightly greased with butter or oil. You can also use a non-stick skillet for easier cooking.

What should I do if my pancake batter is too thick?

If your batter seems too thick, add a little more milk, a tablespoon at a time, until you reach a pourable consistency.

Can I make the pancake batter ahead of time?

Yes, you can prepare the batter ahead of time and store it in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours. Just give it a gentle stir before using.

How do I store leftover pancakes?

To store leftover pancakes, let them cool completely, then stack them with parchment paper in between, place them in an airtight container, and refrigerate for up to 3 days.

What toppings go well with gingerbread pancakes?

Gingerbread pancakes are delicious with maple syrup, whipped cream, fresh fruit like bananas or berries, or even a sprinkle of powdered sugar.

How can I ensure my pancakes are fluffy?

Do not overmix your batter; it’s okay if there are a few lumps. Overmixing can lead to dense pancakes.

Is it safe to eat raw pancake batter?

It is generally not recommended to eat raw pancake batter due to the risk of foodborne illness from raw eggs and flour.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For gluten-free options, substitute all-purpose flour with a gluten-free flour blend. To make the dish dairy-free, use almond milk or any plant-based milk and replace butter with coconut oil. For a vegan alternative, replace the egg with a flax egg (1 tbsp ground flaxseed mixed with 2.5 tbsp water) and use maple syrup instead of brown sugar. Ensure the molasses used is vegan-friendly.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing with Gingerbread Pancakes, consider serving them with crispy bacon or sausage links for a savory contrast. A dollop of whipped cream or a sprinkle of powdered sugar can elevate the sweetness. For beverages, a warm cup of spiced chai or hot chocolate with a hint of cinnamon complements the flavors beautifully. A glass of freshly squeezed orange juice can also add a refreshing citrus note.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Gingerbread Pancakes warm on a large platter, stacking them high for a visually appealing presentation. Drizzle generously with maple syrup and top with a sprinkle of crushed gingerbread cookies or pecans for added texture. For a festive touch, garnishing with fresh cranberries or a few sprigs of mint can enhance the seasonal feel. Add a side of seasonal fruit like sliced apples or pears to balance the richness of the pancakes.

Gingerbread Pancakes

25 min
$5
350 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

glutendairyegg

Dietary Tags:

vegetarian

Cuisine:

American

Course:

BreakfastBrunch

Tags:

breakfasteasysweet

Description

Fluffy pancakes infused with warm gingerbread spices, perfect for a cozy breakfast.

Ingredients

  • all-purpose flour: 1 cup
  • baking powder: 2 tsp
  • baking soda: 1/2 tsp
  • ground ginger: 1 tsp
  • ground cinnamon: 1 tsp
  • ground nutmeg: 1/4 tsp
  • brown sugar: 2 tbsp
  • salt: 1/4 tsp
  • milk: 1 cup
  • egg: 1 large
  • molasses: 2 tbsp
  • butter: 2 tbsp, melted
